instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.P3V3S0_EN: What is P3V3S0_EN? This signal enables the PP3V3_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesnâ€™t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Hi,
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  that  doesn't boot. It has green light (only with original charger) the fan spins,  it consumes 250mA on PSU, but don't have any USB activity.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 5.0 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> = 1.05V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> = 1.79V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> =1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0V

I notice that <CAPACITOR>C5010</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C5017</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C5002</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C5007</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C5008</CAPACITOR> had corrosion, so I lifted up all of them, and saw that some pads were burnt. I think that the  mac should power on without those caps, but it doesn't. Am I wrong?

Can you help me?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Hello hgoncalves,

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is missing, but you have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, first you need to check whether you have <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL>. This signal will open load switch <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> and allow 3.3 S5 to become 3.3V S0. Please have a look at page 59/76 of the schematics and inspect those resistors.

The laptop should boot even without those caps removed, you can add them later and run jumper wires instead of missing pad/trace). Right now, you need to find out what is happening with necessary voltages. On page 62 you have all power rails. the best is to go through all of them and which are missing (
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>...)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message: Be sure no short at <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> first.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Hi,

<SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>  is not shorted, and i don't have  <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL>  (0V).

I have 3.3V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR>) but 0V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R8185</RESISTOR>) witch i think is needed to create <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL>, so i think that it may be the <CHIP>U8180</CHIP>. Am I right?.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Check if it gets 3V at pin 5.
If yes, and no corrosion on its pins, change it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message: If you have 3.3V on <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> ( <SIGNAL>M_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL> ) or on the probe point connected to the pin 1 of <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> and you have 3.3V on <CAPACITOR>C8180</CAPACITOR>  (connected to pin 5), then you need to change <CHIP>U8180</CHIP>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message: I replaced <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> but same result. 3.3V on pins 1 and 5, and 0.02V on pin 4

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Then it is possible that this output line is shorted, but if <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> works OK, then there would be a voltage drop on 3.3V S5 line. Did you check <CAPACITOR>C8186</CAPACITOR>?
When measuring voltage at pin 4, did you also measure on probe test point near <RESISTOR>R8185</RESISTOR>? I would remove <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> and check continuity between pin 4 on the motherboard and resistors <RESISTOR>R8185</RESISTOR>(6)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8180</CHIP> has internal pull-up resistor.
So, it should generate 3V on its output directly; check diode mode to ground there.
Also you can remove <RESISTOR>R8184</RESISTOR>/85/87, one by one, and see if voltage goes high.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
you were right. <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL> was shorted and i replaced <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> (it was getting hot). That short is gone, but now I have 0V on pin 1(<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL> not shorted) and 3.3V on pin 5 of <CHIP>U8180</CHIP>. 
I have <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> (3.4V) and <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> seams to be ok. Can it be <TRANSISTOR>Q8131</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Check for knocked off components.
Possibly aplied heat affected something else on the board.

Which voltages do you get now?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Nothing is out of place.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> =1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
You are missing even <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> now; possibly not even <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>.
So check the basic signals from power on sequence.
Start with PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Please have a look at [URL='https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uvRaC3VUYR0&list=PLkVbIsAWN2lsjujIe9sbzDDXwQJHShVGI']this video[/URL]!
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is created in the PCH. I hope the problem is something more trivial, like shown in the video.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 0.634V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> = 0.715V"
I asked that 4 days ago...
How can the board start without correct RTC signals??

Check <RESISTOR>R1302</RESISTOR> and R/<CAPACITOR>C1300</CAPACITOR>.
Possibly bad PCH, or accumulated crap underneath.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Sorry, couldn't work on it...
<RESISTOR>R1302</RESISTOR> and R/<CAPACITOR>C1300</CAPACITOR>.  seams to be OK (resistance values are normal).
Do you think it is worth it to do a ultra-sound, or a small reflow on the PCH?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
Remove <CAPACITOR>C1300</CAPACITOR>.
If <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> still low, then heat PCH to 180-200 degrees for 15-20s.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power on
threads.message:
No luck.
Lifted up the <CAPACITOR>C1300</CAPACITOR> and reflow the PCH, but same result
